text:
If your bread is too dense try beating the batter longer next time. In the original recipe It stated to beat for 5 min. I know this seems extreme, but it will help. This helps whip more air into it. When Allrecipes listed this recipe they modified it.  Patricia Bergstrom

None
text:
since it's impossible just to follow a recipe ( and believe me, this cornbread is as good as gold when you do the original ), here are a few variations on the theme which jazzed it up for my picky crew: switch ingredient amounts between the cornmeal and flour; let the milk/cornmeal mixture sit for 10 minutes or so and whisk it a few times; use half white and half light brown sugar; mix the whole batch for at least 5 min. on low speed; bake in a glass pyrex and reduce oven temp by 25 degrees.  then soften some butter in the microwave, mix with honey and a pinch of salt ( to taste ) and slather this righteous bread with that spread.

userID:

Display Name:
cookinlove

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you try this cornbread, with a few suggestions, you will never make another cornbread recipe.  I rated Grandmothers Buttermilk Cornbread from this site as the best ever, but this surpasses that one by a long shot!  It is very important though to read reviews where the submitter of the recipe says to beat the entire concoction for at least 5 minutes before dumping it into the pan to cook.  I must admit, I was very skeptical - every bread recipe in the world talks about not over-mixing.  But I couldn't find my staple recipe and feeling adventurous, I gave it a try.  So glad that I did!  What I did was 1) Half the recipe and only use 1/4 c sugar instead of 1/3 c. 2) While the milk/cornbread mixture is sitting for 5 minutes, give it a good whip with a whisk 5-6 times, 3) Beat the entire concoction at least 5 minutes (and set a timer) before dumping in the pan, 4) Put about 2 TBL butter in a 10" cast iron skillet to melt in your 400 degree oven for about 5 minutes while you are beating the mixture then take it out and pour in the cornbread mixture (believe me - this will make all the difference in the world - it is very important to cook it with a cast iron skillet) 5) Only bake it for 20 minutes!  This will yield you the most fluffy, corny, airy, moist, slightly sweet but not to powerful to go with anything, piece of cornbread heaven in the world!!!  Thanks for such a wonderful recipe!!  It is my staple from now on - I am not even looking for another!

text:
I made this for a big gathering this past Sunday.  I made it to go along with both a white chili and a regular beef chili.  It was awesome!!! Note that I did make the suggested changes below: I used 2 cups cornmeal and 1-1/2 flour; I soaked the cornmeal for 10 minute; I added 1 full cup of sugar and I baked it at 375.  It was wonderful.  This one's a keeper!  Thanks y'all!

I followed the advice to whisk the mixture for 5 minutes before pouring it in the muffin pan, and there were no problems.  I lowered the cooking time to 25 minutes since we chose to make muffins.  This recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
My husband and I have made this recipe several times and we love it.  This is a sweet, dense cornbread, but I find that it's sweetness is a good complement to a spicy chili.  It keeps fairly well, but any cut edges will dry out quickly -- however, since the bread is dense, it will still be moist just beyond the cut edge. Only cut off as much as you plan to eat at a time.  We also like this at breakfast with a little molasses.

text:
I've been looking for this recipe for 30 years -- this cornbread was amazing!  I'm not sure why some people said it didn't have a lot of "corn" taste, as I thought it was perfect.  It is a heavy, sweet, cornbread, so if you're looking for light and fluffy "old-fashioned" (dry) cornbread this may not be what you're looking for.  I threw in a can of (drained) Niblets corn, and per other reviewers, adjusted the corn meal and flour to 1-3/4 Cups each, and it was the recipe I've always wanted.  My husband isn't a big cornbread fan, and he couldn't stop eating it.  I served with the "White Bean 'n' Ham Soup" on this site, and it was a perfect meal.

text:
I run a cafe that serves comfort food, including three soups a day. When I wanted to try cornbread with my chili one day i tried this recipe. It was such a hit that I make it to serve as an option to buns every day. The customer response has been terrific. I have substituted portions of whipping cream when I've needed to use it. I double the recipe and pour it into two lasagna pans. It stores well in a plastic box and I stick it under the flame for a few seconds to crisp up for serving. Awesome!

text:
I made half of this recipe as muffins (12 regular) and baked for about 15 minutes.  I also used melted butter instead of oil.  I liked the more cake-like texture as I don't care for the more gritty taste of the corn meal.
**I just tried using honey in place of the sugar. . .I don't recommend this.  The cornbread is soft and almost chewy.  I'll stick to using sugar as the recipe turned out great that way.

text:
I just read some of the reviews on this that said that they didn't like it and that they said it was tasteless and one said it was DRY!!!  You had to have done something wrong.  I have been making this for 2 yrs now and it is the best D*** corn bread we have ever tasted.  My Mother is from the South and my Father from the North, and they both say that it's the best they have ever had.  I am a very accomplished cook and know what good food is and have quite an sophisticated pallet for food.  If you have read the other reviews that said that it wasn't good, DON'T listen to them.  If you follow the recipe right, you won't be disappointed.  One thing I do though, is measure the corn meal in a measuring bowl ( such as Pampered Chef) and them pour said amount of milk into the bowl, whisk it together and let it sit.  When it settles, it might measure less, but don't worry about it, it'll be fine.  It measures less for me and I get told how great it is.  Thank you so much for this recipe! :D I hope you enjoy it.

text:
This recipe GREAT.  Easy, fast and ALWAYS turns out perfect.  I have a business where I cook meals @ home to sell to families and I have used this recipe over and over...raving reviews.  Also as a manager of a bed and breakfast I served it with Chicken & Dumplings for dinner, slam dunk every time.  ONE minor adjustment, when it says "grease the pan", I put in 1/2 stick of butter in the pan, place the pan in the oven to melt the butter. When all the butter is melted, I pour in the batter.  Gives the edges a crispy, buttery taste.  To die for!

text:
Easy and delicious.  Reduced sugar to 1/2 cup.  I like to sprinkle paprika on top for a little color.  I generally serve 1/3 with dinner (usually chili) and freeze 2/3 of the bread in a plastic freezer bag.  This helps control our carb intake (yum!).  The other 2/3 of the cornbread can be thawed for other meals.  I like to slice it into cubes and toast it in the oven to accompany stews, chili, salads as a hearty crouton.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this and it turned out perfectly! I must admit, I made several adjustments based on everyone's comments, so my 5-star rating is a bit skewed. I increased the cornmeal to 2 cups, reduced milk to just over 2 cups, reduced flour to 1 1/2 cups, increased sugar to approx 3/4 cup, and reduced oil to a bit less than 1/2 cup. It cooked pretty quickly in my oven - only about 20 min and it was done. We lived in Montreal in the 70's and used to by these things called Corn Toasties from the grocery store (so good with melted butter!). This flavour & consistency is the closest I can remember to how those tasted.

text:
UMMM!  Word to the wise: soak the corn meal for about 15 minutes - no more or the bread will be too dense and raw or doughy in the middle as one baker commented.  I added a tablespoon of vinegar to the milk for that buttermilk effect. Tnis is one of the very best corn breads I've ever served - a hint of crisp on the outside and just perfect crumb on the inside... Thanks for sharing!

text:
Best cornbread I've ever had! I did use half whole wheat flour and half all-purpose - which is normal for me when I bake.  Also, I did cut the sugar back to 1/2 cup.  The first time I made this I baked it 30 min. at 350 by accident - it turned out good, but I baked it at 400 for almost 30 min. the second time and I think that was better.  Soaking the cornmeal makes a huge difference in the texture - I ended up soaking mine for 45 minutes while preparing other food for the meal, but 5 minutes should work just as well. I served this with baked Ham, then we had the leftovers (because it make a lot!) for breakfast the next morning. Very very good recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only gave it 4 stars since I did make changes.  I swapped the flour and cornmeal requirements since I wanted a bit more 'corn' taste.  I also added 1 tsp vanilla since that is what I've tasted in the corn breads I like best.  I also dropped the bake temp to 375 deg. for 25 minutes and still ended up with a 'crust' on the bottom and sides but a light moist cornbread.

I did not 'over' stir for 5 minutes as so many have suggested, as  this is how gluten develops.  Muffins and cornbread should be stirred only long enough to get all the ingredients stirred in and may even have a few lumps.

This is not as dense as a pound cake but it's not as fragile as many cornbreads.  It would hold up well to bean dishes or chili.

text:
I usually make the 'Grandma's' recipe but decided to try this one because it didn't call for buttermilk.  It was not a successful tria. and I ended up dumping the entire batch.  I did take away the technique of soaking the cornmeal in the buttermilk, which I did in Grandma's recipe.  It came out more delicious.  Thanks for the tip.  
To anyone making this recipe I would definitely advise against using so much flour (maybe 1 - 1 1/2 cups) and over mixing.  I'd mix it by hand until just blended.  I followed the instructions and it came out dense but in a doughy way and flavorless.

country:
None
text:
This is my go to cornbread recipe with a couple of modifications.

I use less sugar most of the time - usually 1/4 cup.  And I always substitute 1 stick of melted butter for the oil.  Occasionally I'll add some frozen corn and green chilies and maybe some cooked breakfast sausage.

To save time, I've started just mixing as I would any other quick bread, mixing dry ingredients and adding wet ingredients, skipping the soaking.  There is probably a difference but we like it fine that way and I like saving those few minutes.

I use a somewhat coarse cornmeal but the bread still has a soft texture.

My husband said the other day that he used to enjoy the box mixes that he always made before we were married but that the cornbread I make now ruined those forever :)

People on here rating low need to check to make sure they followed the recipe exactly and read the 1st comment which was by the author.  Allrecipes edited out the very important step of beating the mixture for 5 minutes.    This recipe is amazing.  It is the sweetest, most dense cornbread recipe I have found.  I don't change the recipe one bit unless making it specially for something in particular.  If I'm serving with chili, I add a bit more sugar to complement the chili.  Sometimes I add corn to it to add the taste, but this recipe exactly as written is fantastic!!!  Just be sure to follow the directions and amounts exactly, especially the first time you make it.  If it turns out dry or anything, you did something wrong.

userID:
71373
Display Name:
NLP408
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
While I don't doubt this is from her mother in law in Canada, it is just the recipe from the back of the Purity cornmeal bag (the most common brand of cornmeal here in Canada). The only thing different is this recipe uses half the baking powder stated on the bag, and it says to leave it soak for 10 minutes.

I use this recipe (with the extra baking powder) all the time, and usually buy my cornmeal bulk, so I refer to this site to get the recipe. I always half the recipe to make 12 cornmeal muffins or 2 mini loaves, since it doesn't really keep. 

Also, you can substitute almond or soy milk just fine in this recipe, and add a lot less sugar or use honey if you want, or whole wheat flour works fine too.

text:
I chose this recipe for the great reviews, lower sodium content and because it uses oil instead of butter.  Due to health concerns, I omitted the salt and substituted light olive oil for the corn oil. I also reduced the sugar to 1/4 c sugar and 1/4 c splenda.  It made 22 medium sized muffins which I baked for 20 minutes.  They were golden brown and yummy.  I decided on muffins because they freeze better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really thought this recipe made a great starting point, but like many other people I made some alterations:

I HALVED the recipe, so this will explain my measurements:

I used 3/4 cup of flour instead of 1 cup, and 1 cup of cornmeal instead of 3/4 cup. Basically put, I switched the cornmeal and flour measurements. I also used CORN GRITS instead of cornmeal because I love the texture.

I used buttermilk instead of milk. And I let the milk and cornmeal sit for about 10 minutes, together.

I also defrosted about 1/2 cup of frozen corn and mushed it up a little bit to bring out the juices and mash the kernels so they aren't so big.

Another person suggested cream corn - great idea! Just make sure to reduce the milk by a little bit if you are going to use cream corn.

I used brown sugar instead of white sugar, I used butter instead of oil, and I used whole wheat flour instead of all-purpose flour.

I baked them in muffin tins for about 20 or so minutes. Delicious! They didn't even need butter or anything. Perfect as is. :)

I really liked this recipe. I've made it twice now. The first time I did exactly as the instructions said. It came out perfect, but I found that after it cooled and the following day the cornbread was a bit crumbly. The second time I added 1/2 cup of plain yogurt and baked them in a muffin pan. The yogurt helped them stay moist even after they were cool and days later.

Display Name:
Lizzy

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best recipe for cornbread I have ever used. I can't ever follow a recipe exactly though so of course I tweeked it just a bit.  As others have mentioned I switched the measurements for the cornmeal and flour to 2 cups cornmeal and only a cup and a half of the flour.  I also whipped the cornmeal and milk quite a few times with a spatula while it soaked.  As for the dry ingredients I sifted them all together twice before adding the wet ingredients and I chose to use golden Cisco melted instead of oil.  I then cooked at 300F instead of 400F and the bread has turned out PERFECT every time!  Edges are golden yellow and just the right crispness and the center is nice and moist! Made this quite a few times already and not sure how anyone can say anything bad about it.  If they do, it's not the recipe, it's them!

A good, basic cornbread recipe. A little dense, but it holds up well to beans. Good flavor, too; not too sweet. Try this at 350 degrees, for only 30 minutes and if you really want something awesome, try mixing in corn grits(NOT regular grits) with the corn meal.  Any combination will do.  I've even tried all corn grits, and it still works.  It definitely adds some crunch to it, and the lower heat and less cooking time makes it SO moist!  Enjoy!

userID:
1761392
Display Name:
Veggie Girl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/209766.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe--I followed it almost exactly (with exception of baking at 375 degrees F and adding 2 tbsp. jalapeno peppers).  The cornbread rose beautifully and was soft and fluffy (not oily, greasy or too crumbly like other recipes I've tried).  Some reviewers spoke of the cornbread being dense/heavy, but I found it to be just the right (however, I let the cornmeal soak for 10 minutes, and I sifted the flour mixture before adding the oil and eggs).  The only drawback is that the cornbread was lacking in flavor, even when I added 2 tablespoons jalapeno pepper (seeded and chopped).  It also was not very sweet (but that's ok, as I like to add honey and butter when I eat it).  I will make this again but I will do as other reviewers suggested and switch the amounts for the flour and cornmeal (2 cups cornmeal and 1 1/2 cups flour) and perhaps reduce the baking powder to 2 1/2 teaspoons.  Also for more flavor, I will add a whole jalapeno (seeded and chopped) and 3/4 cup thawed frozen corn.  I think that this is a great foundation for cornbread that you can alternate it to your own personal tastes!

0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this cornbread for a chili party with some minor changes and it was a huge hit.  I substituted 1/2 cup of sour cream for 1/2 cup of the milk; 1/3 cup of honey for 1/3 cup of the sugar; and butter for the vegetable oil.  Add 1 cup frozen, thawed sweet yellow corn.  I whisked all of the dry ingredients including cornmeal together and all of the liquid ingredients together.  Combined both and and let sit for 10 minutes.  I heated the ungreased pan in oven for 10 minutes, sprayed the hot pan with vegetable oil then poured batter into the hot pan.  My oven had preheated for about 20 minutes to insure that it was very hot and I baked the cornbread for a full 35 minutes.  The result was a crusty exterior with a moist, dense, sweet bread.

text:
My teenage sons devoured nearly this entire pan in one sitting, delicious...after reading the reviews, I decided to use a classic technique to help improve the texture: let eggs come to room temp, separate, beat the whites until they form soft peaks, prepare recipe as directed gently folding in the egg whites last. This helps add volume (air) and can be used for any cake, quickbread, pancake etc. recipe.

text:
Tried so many other cornbread recipes, and this is the best so far. Moist and sweet...nice with butter. I halved the recipe but used 1 cup cornmeal and 3/4 cup white flour instead. Also used both white and brown sugar. Whisked the batter for 5 minutes before pouring in the pan as advised by others. My oven cooked it in only 25 min at 375.

text:
I made this recipe exactly according to the recipe (for once) and the end result was good.  Had I reviewed the recipe last night after we ate it for supper, it would have received 5 stars, but I waited until today and I'm glad I did.  While the bread was very good last night (still warm out of the oven), it was significantly dryer today (requiring a lot of butter to give it some moisture).  The texture of the bread was almost cake-like, but I suspect that's because I soaked the cornmeal in the milk for 5 minutes, but then I also whipped all the ingredients in my Kitchenaid mixer for another 4 or 5 minutes.  So I will likely make this again because the flavour was very good, but next time I won't mix it for quite as long.

text:
This cornbread recipe is the best one I've ever tried.   It is moist and cake-like with a hint of sweetness.  In the past two weeks every family with a new baby or an illness has received cornbread along with chicken and rice soup.  I've gotten great responses and now am sharing the recipe (and the website) with loads of friends.  Just don't forget to mix the batter for more than 5 minutes!  I've even put the 15 servings size recipe in an 8x8 pan, decreased the oven temperature to 350 degrees and left it in for twice as long.  It turns out great!  Thanks Patricia B. for sharing this recipe!

I made this about an hour ago to go with some chili I am making for dinner. I have been making cornbread the same way my whole life using a traditional southern recipe passed down through my family. So it was a big step for me to try making it another way. This is pretty good bread. My family nor I like sweet cornbread so I didn't use the amount of sugar called for. I have always wanted to make mexican cornbread. This seems like it would be the perfect recipe to use when making that, so next time I am going to add other ingredients for that. I'm not sure if I like this better than my usual cornbread, but it is a bit different and worth making again.

text:
This tastes great right out of the oven.  It's slightly sweet, and because I didn't soak the cornmeal in the milk for the whole 5 minutes, this cornbread has the firm texture similar to that of Cracker Barrel.  I shared some with a couple of friends, and they described it as tasting like Jiffy cornbread.  I used egg substitute and skim milk which did not detract from the flavor at all.  Also, I had to  halve the recipe (ran low on cornmeal) so I baked this in a loaf pan at 375F for 35 minutes.

text:
I've been looking for a good cornbread recipe - most of the ones I've tried have been really dry, crumbly, and tasteless.  This one is great though, I will definitely be making it again.  I followed others' suggestions and let the cornmeal soak for 10 minutes rather than 5.  I also switched the flour and cornmeal measurements.  I had to make a couple of other adjustments as well - I only had 1 egg so I used it and 1/4 cup egg substitute.  I was also just shy with the vegetable oil so I added some olive oil to make up the difference.  I also added some fresh corn kernels.  I might add a tad more sugar next time to see how it tastes as I like my cornbread a bit on the sweet side.  Overall, VERY tasty cornbread recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
I too give this 5 stars! I took other reviewers' advice and switched the amounts of the corn meal and the flour (which I recommend), and after letting the milk and corn meal sit for 10 minutes, I mixed everything with my electric hand held mixer for 5 minutes. I then baked it on 375 in a 9 by 13 glass dish for 30 minutes, which was perfect....really kept it moist. It's the perfect consistency and doesn't fall apart at all. The only complaint I have is that I added too much sugar. I used the new Splenda baking product that is a blend of Splenda and sugar. Pay attention if you do this, as you need to cut your portions by half per instructions on the back of the bag! I didn't and the cornbread was way too sweet. Also, buttermilk was perfect with this. This is now my new cornbread recipe.

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/12010.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cornbread tastes good and is easy to make.  Goodbye Jiffy Corn Muffin Mix!

It has become a staple in our house.  I usually cut my recipe in half and baked it in a cast iron skillet.

[Scaled half-recipe ingredients:
3/4 cup cornmeal
1 1/4 cups milk
1 cup flour
1/2 tablespoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/3 cup white sugar
1 egg
1/4 cup vegetable oil]

**update:
I originally rated this recipe back in 2004.  I'm back in 2016 with an update:

I have never made jalapeno cornbread, but I tried it using half of this recipe, folding in 2 diced jalapeno peppers after mixing everything else together.  It was awesome, and now I am a cornbread rock star!

text:
Ok..I had EVERY intention to follow this recipe to the letter.  I thought it would go well with my split-pea soup.  What happened?  Star Trek happened.  One of my favorite episodes.  1. I used 3 cups of cornmeal.  2.  1 cup of (self-rising) flour.  I whisked the eggs, then 1/3 cup of sugar, salt, and I then I poured in, 4.  1 and 3/4 cup of milk that was about to sour, smelled edible to me. 5.  I heated up the oil in the pan I was using 6.  Then poured the liquid into the dry ingredients. 7.  I stirred about 2 minutes 8.  Then poured in the heated oil.  9.  I rushed through this hoping I could finish before my kid got home from school. 10. Then I realized that I should have read the entire recipe and stirred..oops mixed for 5 minutes at least to make it lighter.  Well forget that, it was on its way to bakersville. With time to spare as Kirk and crew got out of the Mirrorverse. The result??  Best freakin' cornbread I have ever made!!  Thank-you so very much!!!

text:
Great cornbread recipe!  I cook it in my cast iron skillet, and it turns out perfect every time.  Make sure that if you use cast iron, you oil it heavily (I use olive oil), and put it in the oven while it's preheating.  You never want to put a cold cast iron skillet in a hot oven!  And besides, it gives the cornbread a beautiful crust!!

I love this recipe!!! It is almost like a cake, very moist, very good tasting. What I did to change the recipe a bit was to put 1/3 cup white sugar and 1/3 cup of brown sugar instead of 2/3 cup of white sugar. I ended up letting the cornmeal and milk mixture sit for 15 minutes. Don't know if this made a difference or not.
I will make this recipe again and again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been searching for a good cornbread recipe (not too dry, not too floury, with just the right amount of sweet) and I think this is it! Because I was short on a few staples, I ended up doing equal parts cornmeal and flour (1 3/4c. each). I also used 1/3c. white sugar and 1/3c. brown sugar.  Otherwise I made the recipe exactly as stated. I even beat the batter for 5 min. with a mixer as many posters recommended. Mine baked in a glass 13x9 inch pan at 400 for 30 min. and it was perfect. Absolutely delicious warm with butter.  I served it with the Zesty Slow Cooker Chicken Barbecue recipe from this site. Homesteader Cornbread is my new go-to cornbread recipe. Thanks!!!

This was excellent cornbread, and not too dry.  I did make a change however, I substituted 1/3 cup of honey and 1/3 cup white sugar instead, because I don't like using so much white sugar and I wanted the extra stickiness of the honey.  Add the honey last so that it doesn't lump up the batter.  Otherwise, I did everything the same and it was so delicious and easy.

text:
Great recipe. I live in Colorado and didn't have any high-altitude baking issues. The only modification I made was reducing the sugar to 1/2 cup, bumping up the salt by a pinch, and substituting a 1/2 cup melted, unsalted butter instead of oil. To prevent clumping, I tempered the warm butter with some of the cooler batter separately, before adding it to the rest of the mix.

userID:
3388544
Display Name:
Rin B
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
---DENSE CORNBREAD--- I’ve read of some people baking very dense cornbreads. I don’t beat the batter for 5 min though (which apparently helps by incorporating air into the batter?) - I’m afraid that might make a chewy cornbread (since overbeating causes gluten from the flour to develop) which I’m not a fan of. I make sure to SIFT the flour into the measuring cup, to ensure I don’t take too much flour (which results in too dense cornbread). It’s best to weigh flour since it’s often packed to various densities when we store it, but if you’re lazy and would rather use cups (like me :) sifting the flour helps hugely. It works for me, so hopefully it helps someone else! :) ---ADD CORN--- If you want to add corn like I did, omit 1/4 cup of milk (since corn releases some water). When you’ve made the batter, mix in 2 cups of frozen corn coated in 2 tbsp flour (helps suspend the corn, I think). ---Other--- I find 1/2 cup sugar is plenty sweet. Great with chili, taco, or on its own. As other reviewers said, switching the amounts between the flour and cornmeal is good (though I don't mind keeping the original amounts), and use half white and half brown sugar. I halved the recipe and baked it in a 10” (I think) round glass pan in my toaster oven for 28-30min – lovely, moist cornbread. I've made the original recipe several times (5 stars!) and lately decided to experiment - very easy with this versatile recipe!

country:
None
text:
This is an easy cornbread recipe that turns out great. I suppose I make quite a few changes, but that's out of personal preference. I'm sure the cornbread would be great as written as well. Here's my changes::: I don't eat eggs, so I use ener-g egg replacer instead. I replace most of the oil with unsweetened applesauce (fewer calories) and use raw turbinado sugar instead of granulated white sugar (raw will give a little more of a crunch to the top, which I prefer.) I use either skim milk or plain light soymilk for these, whichever I have on hand. & lastly I don't use a pan, I line a 12 count muffin tin and it's the perfect amount of mix for 12 muffins. This is now my go to cornbread recipe (with my preferred changes of course).

text:
Made this for my southern family & they loved it.  

I used only about 5 teaspoons of sugar;  also used self rising flour, so left out the salt & baking powder.

Instead of a pan, I used a cast iron skillet, which I put just enough oil in the bottom of skillet to cover it completely, set it in the oven for about 5 minutes to heat the oil.
(Test if ready by flicking a few drops of water from your fingertips on oil, if it pops up oil is hot enough.)

Take out hot skillet and pour in mixture as recipe advises.  Cook as directed.  Bottom will come out nice and crusty with nice flavor.

text:
I made several changes based on other reviews and my own tastes. First I too did 2 cups corn meal and 1.5 cups all purpose flour In addition I used only 1 cup of milk along with a can (about 1.5 cups) of cream corn. I then beat it for a minute or so with a hand mixer. Also I added a bit of lemon juice to that batter and finally I used butter instead of oil. The results...a very nice cornbread that I hope my guests will enjoy!

Display Name:
SolarSoda

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3057.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A hit with picky eaters! I did not follow the recipe as listed here on the website. Instead I followed the suggestions of numerous cooks here: switched the cornmeal/flour ratios (2 c. cornmeal, 1 1/2 c. flour); soaked the cornmeal and milk for WELL more than 10 minutes (more like 20); did 1/3 white sugar, 1/3 brown sugar, which I packed, not sure if I was supposed to pack it or not; baked it at 375 degrees for 25 minutes in a 13x9" glass, Pyrex baking dish (electric stove).

Other changes I made: used almond milk instead of cow's milk and King Arthur whole wheat flour. Admittedly it did have a slight, wheat-y taste to it, but not bad. It came out delicious! I like sweet-ish cornbread and this was about the same as I would expect from the good ol' Jiffy box. This was my first attempt at cornbread from scratch and it was a winner!

One last note: I wonder if the low raters here measured their flour correctly? Not everyone knows how to measure flour (my mom taught me at a very young age). I spooned the flour into the measuring cup and then leveled it off with a knife, moving the straight edge of the knife across the top of the measuring cup back and forth until the flour was level. Of course any straight edge will work, I've just always used a knife. I imagine, if you measure the flour wrong that might make your cornbread taste real dry.

text:
Wowza! I followed other reviewer's suggestions ~~~ then watched the angles kiss the tongues of my guests.
Here's what I did:
1) Switched the flour ratios
2) Let cornmeal/milk mix stand 10 minutes
3) Used 1/3 C. white sugar & 1/3 light brown
4) Beat the batter for 5 minutes w/ a whip 
5) Added 1/2 can creamed corn 
6) Warmed & whisked together equal amounts of butter and honey, then drizzled on top of each slice.
7) Served with ham & bean soup ...but that's another story.

I just took a pan of this delicious cornbread out of my oven and I can tell you this....it's wonderful!  A teensy-weensy corner seems to be missing.  *shrugs*  It's just me living here so I halved the recipe and baked it in an 8 x 8 pan. city:

country:

text:
What I made was five starred, but I made a few modifications: A lot of people were going to eat it so I added another half of the recipe. I swapped the amounts of cornmeal and flour, and added polenta. First mixed the 4 1/4c milk with 3c cornflour and 1/4c polenta. I added more milk because it seemed like it could use more moisture. Let sit for 15 minutes. Added 3 eggs and 3/4c oil and mixed well. Combined 2c flour, 1.5T baking powder, 1.5t salt and 1c sugar (could have only put 2/3c though). Then added to the cornmeal mix. Poured most of it in a preheated, oiled cast iron skillet and baked.  The rest I made into muffins. It was a hit with all ten people who devoured it!

I like cornbread when I go to restaurants, but never had any success when trying recipies at home. Usually they come out bland, dry or just tastes gross. I thought I'd give it another go again after stumbling upon this recipe...and is it ever good! This will be the only recipe I use from now on. It was moist and slightly sweet. We had it with a spanish soup and it was so tasty. I might try throwing in some extras next time like green onions or something, but plain is also very good.

text:
Sweet and cakey like we Yanks love it!  Great flavor/texture.  Nice crown, even at high altitude!  One problem, I checked it after 30 mins at 400 and it was browned but still soupy.  Reduced temp to 350 and cooked an additional 40 minutes.  Still turned out good, but barely done in the center and almost too brown on the edges.  Next time, I'd just do 350 for at least an hour.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure what all the complaints were about.  The bread I made was fabulous.  Even my picky 16 month old had a couple of pieces.  It came out moist and crumbly with just the right amount of sweetness.  I did modify the recipe somewhat and took the advice of a few.  Here's what I did (I was only making it for me and my daughter so I halved the recipe):  replaced half the white sugar with brown; added just over 1/2c of frozen corn; beat the mixture on low for 5 minutes; baked in a loaf pan at 375 degrees for appx 37 minutes.  The only things I may do differently in the future would be use all brown sugar and add some chopped green chilies (I like it spicy).  I will make this again.  Thank you for sharing!  :)

None
text:
This really is top-notch cornbread!  Slight changes I made: grease a 12" iron skillet and set it in the oven as the oven heats up. I stir the wet ingredients into the dry and mix just till they are blended then I let the batter rest again another 5 minutes before pouring it into the hot skillet. This makes the batter puff up nicer I think. The hot skillet makes for an outstanding crust. I'm making this cornbread again -- today!!  It's awesome with some frozen corn tossed in the batter too.

text:
I honestly don't know why I made this.  I'm not a corn bread person - never have been.  I made chili for dinner on this cold, snowy evening and, for some inexplicable reason, corn bread sounded like a good side.  Made this just as written except baked it in a Pampered Chef 4-section mini loaf pan (vs. the 9x13 pan).  This came out just plain yummy.  Corn bread, where have you been all my life?!  I thought that making the mini loaves would shorten the time but I still needed to cook it the full 35 minutes (might've been due to my geriatric oven) but this was really good.  I did not see the note about mixing it for 5 minutes so next time I will have to try that but, even without the extra mixing time, no complaints from this corn bread hater!

text:
This is a great cornbread recipe and almost exactly what I've been searching for.  I grew up in Texas and my mom always used Martha White's Cornbread Mix.  However, living in Boston now I cannot find that in my stores.  The only change I made to the recipe is that I use far less sugar.  I used only 1/4 cup as I don't like my cornbread sweet.  I also think it could of used maybe 1/2 tsp more salt...maybe.  I'm going to try it again today and I'll will update my review to confirm if that was a wise addition.  Also, I make my cornbread in a 10 inch cast iron skillet.  I put about a tblsp of vegetable oil in the skillet (just enough to coat the entire bottom of the skillet) and let the skillet heat up in the oven before I pour in the cornbread batter.  It comes out nice and crisp on the edges that way.  (Just the way my mom and grandma did it!)***UPDATE***  I made used 1 1/2 tsp of salt and it really made a difference in the flavor.  Now I have the PERFECT cornbread recipe!

text:
I used corn oil, instead of vegetable oil. After all, this is a corn-based recipe, and it's a bit healthier choice. It made a great accompaniment to the Boilermaker Tailgate Chili recipe. 
March 2017 update: although I've made this several times, I've down-rated my initial rating. Because it's quite dense,  I took another reviewer's suggestion and used an electric beater and beat the mixture for 5 min.   It made no difference...if anything, it came out ever more dense, to the point that it looked like it hadn't baked through enough. I even tried baking for another 15 min, but there was no improvement.  I won't be using this recipe again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making homemade cornbread, and I really liked it. I made the suggested changes about reversing the cornmeal and flour amounts, used 1/3 C white sugar and 1/3 C light brown sugar, let the cornmeal & milk (I used soy milk) sit for ~7 minutes, and mixed the batter for 5 minutes exactly. I also added 1/4 C honey to the batter for extra sweetness. I baked it in a 9x13 pan at 375 for 30 minutes. The result? Yum! Yes, it was a bit cakey, like other reviewers said, but I personally like cakey rather than crumbly. The taste could have been a bit stronger... it was lacking some flavor for some reason. But overall, very tasty and very easy to make. Be advised, this makes a LOT! If you're not having a feast of some sort, I'd suggest just making half the recipe. I don't know how I'm going to eat the rest of mine!

text:
Absolutely delicious! If you want a more savory (less sweet), fluffy, crumbly cornbread- then this is NOT the recipe you are looking for! If you want a sweet, very moist and dense cornbread--almost like a corn cake that can completely stand alone, not just as a side--then this is it. YUMMY! Great with butter after baked or without. For once a recipe me entire family gobbles up. And I have picky eaters! This is the ONLY recipe I use and have made it many, many times. I have successfully used powdered milk and water in place of liquid milk and it tasted no different. We also use fresh ground cornmeal from a local mill- it really makes this recipe even that more delish!

text:
perfect. not too sweet, not too grainy, nice texture, golden color. i loved it. the ONLY thing is....it starts to get stale around the sides really quickly. my advice is to leave it in the pan you baked it in, and cover it while still warm. (not HOT though) that way the cover will keep some moisture in. i just had a piece the next day and it's still very moist and not stale.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-01-14T07:27:54.78
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
1358950
Display Name:
ANTILOPE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
26
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1962.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the following changes for a ligher corn bread with a nice bottom crust. Spray canola oil to coat the inside of a 10-inch cast iron skillet. Place skillet in cold oven and turn on oven and heat to 400 F. 

Mix 1-1/2 cups of corn meal....1/2 cup all purpose flour....1/4 cup granulated sugar....1 tablespoon baking powder....3/4 teaspoon salt. Wisk together in a mixing bowl.

In a 2-cup pyrex measuring cup add....1-1/4 cups milk....2 eggs. Wisk until smooth. Heat in microwave 45-seconds to bring to room temperature. Add 1/3 cup canola oil. Wisk until smooth.

Wisk wet ingredients into dry ingredients. Wisk until smooth. Pour batter into the heated cast iron skillet. Bake 30 minutes or until knife inserted in center comes out clean. You can also use a non-preheated 9x13 inch baking dish.

I was looking for a recipe for cornbread that wasnt TOO sweet. If  I wanted to make cake.... I would =) I dont want to. I want to make cornmeal,haha. This recipe was great. I switched the quantities for flour and cornmeal and let the cornmeal and milk set for 10 min. per  others suggestions. I also made the recipe to be 1 1/2 times and then had more then enough to  fit in a 9 x 13 pan. This made it possible to reduce the temperature to 375 and produce really thick cornbread slices like they have at Marie Calendars! I loved it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Recipe - Thanks! I'm an experimenter, so here's what I did different (for a 1/2 recipe yealding 7.5 searvings)...1 C. 1% milk + 1/4 C. whipping cream (that's what I had), 3/4 C. flour + 1/4 C. ground flax seeds (for more fiber & omega 3 & less carbs), 1/3 C. unpacked brown sugar.  Hand whisked for 5 full min. Baked in an oiled glass loaf pan for 45min.  Came out golden & crisp on outside w/nice crack down center.  Tastes crunchy on the outside, very moist & just the right density/fluffyness on the inside. Like it a bit sweeter (I guess I shouldn't have cut down ;) ).  I will use 1/3 C. packed brown sugar next time, and maybe add more flax seeds for a nuttier texture. It's a keeper!

What we didn't like:  other than being a little sweet, this cornbread was pretty bland. text:
I'm from the south and have tasted A LOT of cornbread.  So believe me when I say this is DELICIOUS!!  I did make some minor changes-- I flip-flopped the flour and corn meal amounts to make sure it didn't have too much of a cake-like texture as others have said.  Also, I kept the amount of sugar the same, BUT I mixed some of it into the batter and reserved a small amount to sprinkle on top just before baking (also per suggestions here).  I didn't think it was too sweet, but it is sweet.  My husband also said it was "good;"  this is a compliment from him because he usually says everything is "okay."  I halved the recipe b/c it was just the two of us, and it just fit into my 8-inch cast iron skillet.  We ate this with the yummy Vegan Black Bean soup also on this site.

Noticed some complaints about this recipe. Did not use an electric mixer. Beat the heck out of the dough. It turned out moist and delicious. Drizzled honey on it just for a little extra sweetness for breakfast. I’m removing one star from it because it is blander than other cornbreads I’ve had. But it’s so easy to fix with different toppings and sauces! I might throw in some fruit next time. Oh and it was a little dense but cornbread is supposed to be! It’s a hearty bread meant for long work days and harsh weather!

text:
5/2017: I made this cornbread recipe for the first time today. I used buttermilk since that is what I had on hand and I use it more often for baking. I also made muffins, and reduced the baking time to 15 minutes. The muffins were soft and moist. Very tender! Wonderful with butter and honey. I think soaking the cornmeal in the milk really helped with the final texture. It has taken me many years to find a decent cornbread recipe that is moist...this is it! Will definitely be making this recipe again in the future!
6-24-19 UPDATE:  Today I made this recipe using my corn-stick pan. They turned out WONDERFUL!! Crispy on the corn imprint side, soft and tender on the inside. Best & most versatile cornbread recipe ever! When I make the batter I whisk it for at least 5 or 6 minutes to make sure it is smooth with no lumps. I also preheat the cast iron pan that's being used and pour the batter into the hot, oiled pan. Perfect every time!  :)

userID:
16728275
Display Name:
Matt Anderson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2776726.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We used a cup and a half of buttermilk and a cup of 2% milk mixed and "fluffed" the corn meal every couple of minutes while the rest of the dry ingredients come together. I place a cast iron skillet in the oven and preheat it at 400*. Half of a white onion and 3 jalapenos (half seeded, half with seeds) finely diced and sweated down then added to the batter for some spice and some color. I use a cup of white sugar vs the recipes 2/3 because I want to taste the sweetness. When the oven is ready, toss two tablespoons of salted butter into the cast iron and let it melt and brown in the oven. This will give an awesome buttery crust to the cornbread. Then add the batter and bake for 25-30 minutes until a toothpick comes out clean. Still my favorite base recipe for my "doctored up" corn bread!

I used this advice: "switch ingredient amounts between the cornmeal and flour; let the milk/cornmeal mixture sit for 10 minutes or so and whisk it a few times; use half white and half light brown sugar; mix the whole batch for at least 5 min. on low speed; bake in a glass pyrex and reduce oven temp by 25 degrees." Plus replaced oil with melted butter.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After trying several cornbread recipes from this site, this one is my favourite and I've made it countless times over the years. These are my pro-tips:  The first thing I do is let the cornmeal soak for at least 5-10 minutes, often longer, as I assemble the remaining ingredients. I usually whisk the egg and add it and the oil to the cornmeal mixture. I sift together all the dry ingredients. Mixing it for at least 5 minutes helps with the fluffiness. I also always use a cast iron pan that I heat up in the oven with some oil (or bacon grease if I have it) in it. Add the batter quickly to the hot pan and put it back into the oven. 

These things ensure a perfect result. I've made half the recipe in the past, and it also always turns out. The cornbread doesn't keep super well (it dries out somewhat though can be revived with a gentle nuke), so only make as much as you can use up within a day or two.

I'm another baker in love with this recipe. It's simply delicious. I have made it as-published (without the extra mixing) and it comes out fine (I like my cornbread a little dense). I've also made it in a loaf pan, and once I worked out the extra cooking time, it's fine. My favorite tweak, however, is to omit the salt and baking powder and use self-rising flour instead. Delicious and fluffy! Thanks for this recipe. It's the only one I use now!

This was a great cornbread recipe. Often when I have tried to make cornbread it is dry and crumbly. Thiis one was not at all. I even used gluten free flour for the added regular flour (coconut flour kind) because my grandson is allergic. Everyone loved it. I did follow the recipe for soaking the corn meal and milk first and then mixing all the ingredients for 5 minutes. I put a glass dish with a tablespoon of butter in the oven while it preheated so the dish was already hot when I added the mix. It was moist and had a good texture.

text:
Loved this recipe with some modifications. First I halved the recipe and subbed heavy cream and 1/2 1/2 for the milk and used melted butter instead of oil. Used a bit more butter than called for. As one reviewer mentioned the submitter of this recipe said it is important to wisk all the ingredients for 5 minutes before pouring batter in to your dish. I did this and my shoulder was not happy with me afterwards lol. It did make for a light, fluffy and MOIST cornbread. Finally found my recipe. Thanks to all the buzzers who helped steer me in the right direction. I took tips from all of you who answered my post. I also only cooked it for 20 minutes and it turned out perfect.

text:
PERFECTION!
I read thru the reviews so I made a few changes as suggested.  For years I have looked for "The Perfect Cornbread Recipe", I have finally found it.
I used 2 1/2 cups corn meal (heirloom, organic blue corn meal), soaked it in the milk (organic) as suggested and then used 1 cup flour (organic wheat flour), I used the 2/3c sugar and it turned out PERFECT!  If you like a sweeter cornbread I would suggest using 1cup sugar but I wouldn't go less than 1/2c sugar, it isn't sweet, at this mixture it is perfect
I love that it makes in a large pan as there are 2 of us and I like to have plenty left over to freeze for an easy dinner night.   
The remaining pieces are cooling now so I may freeze them!
THANK YOU FOR A GREAT RECIPE!!!!

text:
Haven't tried this particular recipe, but since its almost word for word of my mother's recipe, think its just fine. The only difference is, my mother used hot milk, or hot water to soak the cornmeal in. And my mother used cornbread as a quick dinner bread all the time, she learned from her mother who learned from hers, so its as authentic as you can get! This idea that cornbread is only authentic if its got corn or hot peppers or whatever the fashion is, is a relatively new ides, corn bread is a quick bread, when you haven't got time to make a more time or space consuming bread, cook it in the skillet, and its even a one dish to mix, and cook!

WOW!  This is now my only recipe for cornbread.  I did add shredded sharp cheddar to the batter. text:
This recipe is great alone, but but kind of tasteless so I tried it with these variations:
•use all brown sugar and use a little more than the original amount
•add a 2 capfulls of pure vanilla extract when mixing all ingredients together
•add 1 can of sweet fancy grade yellow corn also when mixing all ingredients together
•and use a little more flour than recipe calls for
If you try this it is much better than the original. I hope this helps! :-)

text:
Normally I make a recipe as written before I play with it, but this time I couldn't help myself. I tweaked the recipe a little, adding an extra 1/4 tsp of baking powder and 2 Tbsp of honey, and substituted for the cow's milk with almond milk since we have a dairy allergy in the household.  

I wanted to make muffins instead of a big pan of cornbread, so I decreased the oven temperature to 375 and filled 24 standard muffin cups 2/3 full.  I baked the muffins for 15 minutes and they turned out nice and light with that hint of honey flavor I was looking for.

text:
I love this cornbread.  I am from the South and make it WITHOUT the sugar.  I use self-rising flour and leave out the baking powder and salt.  And I always use olive oil instead of a vegetable oil.  OK, so mine seems like almost a different recipe, but it's good.  I think the soaking the corn meal in the milk must make the good difference between this and ordinary cornbread.

text:
Delicious flavour.  I added about 1/4 cup parmesan cheese to the dry ingredients and reduced sugar to 1/4 cup.  I beat the mixture for the 5 minutes as suggested by many reviewers and somehow it didn't work for me.  I made the bread into muffins and they didn't rise at all.  It was like eating little cornbread tarts, but with a little garlic butter spread over the warm cornbread, it more than made up for the lack in height.  Next time will try just folding the wet and dry ingredients together and then baking.  Definitely worth another try.

text:
This is good if you don't want a super sweet, really cake-y cornbread.  This is real cornbread.  Great with chopped jalapenos (mix them in with the flour to get them even), cheese, and chopped poblanos on top.  Make sure to beat it for 5 minutes. It really does help.  Great as a base for taco salad or Navajo tacos as a change.  This works well with whole wheat, as well.  Just lessen the wheat by about 1/4 - 1/2 cup.  And beat really really well.

text:
This cornbread is a bit different than the kind I was raised eating.  Much sweeter and more cake like than I am use to eating.  My kids really enjoyed it.  I used buttermilk instead of milk and used an iron skillet that was hot when I put in the batter (gives it a crisper crust).  Good but I think I will follow the recommendation next time to switch the amounts of flour and cornmeal to give it more of a corn taste.

I have made it several more times.  Definitely switch the amounts for the cornmeal and the flour.  Let it soak properly and I agree with the others to stir that batter for 5 minutes at the end.

This recipe is great!  I followed the basic premise of the recipe and only changed 2 things... I cut the sugar in half and did 1/3 cup honey and 1/3 cup sugar, and I substituted applesauce for the oil just to cut down on the fat a bit.  My very picky dad and husband both LOVED this cornbread recipe - despite hating every other one I have ever made.  So I guess this is the "keeper" recipe.

This was dense and kinda gelatinous.  I did what others recommended - I beat it in the machine for over 5 minutes, but it did not help. text:
Very delicious flavor, delicate crumb--made a few changes, of course. I halved the recipe to make muffins, it made 8 lofty beauties. I cut down the sugar a little, added 1 1/2 tsp baking powder, as well as about 1/2 C cheddar-jack cheese and about 1/4 chopped chilies (sorry, I don't know what kind--somewhere between jalepenos and green chilies on the hotness scale). Baked at 400 for 15 minutes. Totally delicious with our barbecued beef, then had one toasted this morning with a scrambled egg on it.

country:
None
text:
This recipe was very moist and a great consistency; however, I felt that it had too much of a flour taste and not enough corn taste.  I did beat the final batter for five minutes, which made the bread rise very nicely in the oven.  Also, I used plain, low-fat soy milk to make the recipe non-dairy.  I think if I ever made this again, I'd definitely add more corn meal and less flour. I just couldn't get over that flour taste.  And I might add some honey or brown sugar in place of some of the white sugar.  This recipe was good but not great.  Thanks, though!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this all the time.  Just got on Allrecipes to print out another copy, because the one I printed a year ago was too used!   Other reviewers mentioned that it goes with chili. I also like it with lots of different soups, like ham and bean.  With five kids, I find it's a great way to stretch many meals. I have substituted whole wheat flour for part of the white flour with good results.  If you would like to decrease the sugar, I have cut the sugar in half and nobody seemed to mind.  Also, I find that my 11-year-old son is able to handle making this recipe with a little supervision.  It's always nice to have a hand.  Enjoy!

text:
To make a smaller amount, I halved this recipe and poured the batter into a bread pan (smaller/deeper) instead of a 9 x 13 pan.  I was worried about it maybe not cooking all the way through but it turned out beautifully!  Otherwise, I followed the original recipe.  The only thing I may try next time is to add half cup of fresh sweet corn (when in season) for some extra texture.  This bread is fantastic to accompany any creamy soup, black bean and ham soup or chili.  It wasn't too sweet, too moist, too dry.  We loved it as is...and I am usually never satisfied with recipes the first time.

I've made this as-is, and I agree with other reviewers that it's also a great base recipe for experimentation. My latest variation was a low-fat, non-dairy, non-wheat version (applesauce instead of oil, rice milk instead of dairy, masa harina in place of flour, and egg substitute just because I was out of eggs). That also worked well, if you need to adapt the recipe for dietary needs.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/926498.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well I'm not sure how people got a dry bread out of this...it's very moist and tender. I like the flavor. The reviewers who said it isn't "very" anything are right. It's just a balanced flavor. I made muffins out of mine, and was perplexed for awhile about why the bottoms got overdone before the tops got done, and then I remembered I switched out the sugar for Splenda. So note to self: (Cook at a lower temp if using all Splenda). Thanks for the recipe! EDIT 11/19/10: This is still our favorite recipe for cornbread. I add just 1/2 cup sugar for a not-too-sweet version, and the full 2/3 for a sweet version (we like both kinds, but with different entrees). Soaking the cornmeal really does make all the difference here -- the cornbread comes out so tender, moist, and fluffy, that it's almost a shame I'm busy dehydrating a batch in the oven for Thanksgiving dressing :=) All that work putting the moistness in just so I can take it back out -- but this is bar none the best cornbread recipe I've tried from here, easily modified to anyone's tastes. Sub melted butter for oil if you like it buttery; or sub buttermilk for milk and switch the baking powder to 1 1/2 tsp. baking powder + 1 1/2 tsp. baking SODA. Do not straight sub whole wheat into this recipe without adding EXTRA liquid, though, I've done that & wasn't impressed with my results. Thanks again for our favorite cornbread!

I topped mine with a bit of butter and honey and it was so good. My mom was in heaven...lol.

text:
A great starter recipe, though I would make quite a few changes. I love the idea of using half white and half brown sugar, adding a little honey, and substituting some of the oil for butter. It has a light corn flavor that slowly builds, so for more of an initial punch I would do as suggested and use more corn meal and less flour. The texture is fantastic and I love that lightly crunchy crust!

This was a great recipe. We made them into mini muffins to go along with a lentil chili, they were such a hit! I made a couple of changes though. This recipe was sweet, moist and not too dense at all!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe. It was very moist. I substituted 3/4 of a cup of the milk with the juice from a can of corn, and also added the corn. I also chopped up some wickles (wicked sweet pepper strips) and added those, they added a little bit of a kick. But, I think that it would have been just as good without those. I would like to add a tip to making cornbread. I bake my cornbread in a cast iron skillet. I put a little bit of canola oil in the skillet and put it in the oven while it is preheating. The hot oil makes the crust crispy, and it doesn't stick. DELICIOUS!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7710143.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband likes a sweet light cornbread that he refers to as Johnny Cake... so I've been looking for awhile for a recipe (besides the Jiffy Mix box). This wasn't it. Based on the reviewers comments, I was expecting a "fluffy" cornbread, which this was not. 
I needed a pan of cornbread & followed the reviewers recommendations to mix the ingredients for 5 minutes. It added air all right - which developed into pockets  - resulting in an uneven top of the pan. At 30 minutes the pan was still pretty pale - so my total backing time was extended to 34 muinutes. The cornbread was done, but it was VERY dense. There are other recipes out there - most notably Golden Sweet cornbread. I'll probably make it the next time and hang this one up as a good try.

text:
This is a great basic recipe but it makes too much for my small family so I cut the recipe in half and used my 8" cast iron skillet to bake.  A more traditional method of baking, make sure you preheat your skillet as you are heating up your oven, I used vegetable shortening just before putting in the batter.  When it sizzles, you know it's gonna be good!  I also reduced the sugar just a bit and instead of adding vegetable oil to the batter, I added melted butter. C'mon - this is cornbread!  Used whipped organic butter with honey when serving.  Family loves this with good old Tuna Noodle Casserole.

First time making cornbread..this recipe is absolutely OUTSTANDING!!!  Some adjustments made:  switch the measurements for cornmeal and flour, substituted melted butter for the oil, added 2/3's of the sugar and the remaining 1/3 honey. text:
This was pretty good, and I was pleased considering it's the first time I've made cornbread that wasn't from a mix!  I halved the recipe and added a touch more salt, plus I used applesauce for half the oil.  Also, I don't have an electric mixer so couldn't beat the batter for 5 minutes.  Regardless, the cornbread is quite tender and lovely.  Next time I'm going to swap the amounts of flour and cornmeal so it has a bit more of the texture I expect from cornbread, and also add honey because we love honey sweetened cornbread. 1/4 cup of frozen corn kernels would be a great addition as well. All in all, I quite liked this recipe and think I'll hang onto it!

text:
This is it! I have been trying to make corn bread for my husband for the past 8 years. Nothing is as good as his Grandmother's (they are from Texas)! When I read this recipe and reviews I fgured it had to be close. The ingredients are about the same as any other corn bread, but the soaking of the corn meal totally changes the texture. It is more dense and almost chewy compared to the fluffy cake like corn bread I usually make. Whahoo! I'm so glad I finally found this recipe! Because you know, in our house, we can't have chili or any soup without corn bread!

text:
Good taste, not too sweet. I came out very dense though and I'd like something with a lighter texture. It tasted like a sweetish fluffy polenta. The batter looked a little too wet to me but I followed the recipe exactly for a change. I even followed the submitters advice to beat for 5 min. to "lighten it". I think that is a really good base and I will work with it to see if I can get what I'm looking for. This recipe has good flavor and it isn't too grainy like some others. I think that soaking the cornmeal is the key here.

text:
This recipe has become our standard cornbread recipe.  It has just the right amount of sweetness, and is suitably dense and moist.  It's not too crumbly, but I would suggest leaving the corn meal to soak a bit longer to help with the graininess - though perhaps this is a problem with the corn meal I use!  It is, of course, fantastic with butter fresh out of the oven, and my wife discovered it makes a great snack when combines with a few slices of Black Forest ham.  There's no better compliment to a nice big bowl of chili.

text:
Very tasty, wonderful recipe. Everyone I make this for loves it. The last friend I made it for says it tastes more like corn cake! Always moist, pleasantly sweet, good corn flavor too. One update: you might want to store these in the fridge. I had them on the counter, and three days later they got a strange smell and I found mold growing inside (probably because they were so moist)! I think this would have been prevented by being in the fridge. Next time, at least in summer, that's where the leftovers will go.

text:
I am used to a more light cornbread so the second time around I made it with half a cup less cornmeal and half a cup more flour. I also added another half tablespoon of BP and it lightened up quiet a bit. I also didn't soak the cornmeal I just mixed all my dry and thn just added the wet and then gave it one good stir! It took about 5 minutes to whip up and about 40 minutes to back. I used a 9x13 ceramic dish. Otherwise I loved the sweetness, just enough and it keeps about 3 days with out drying out.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe!! I did follow the advise of the other reviewers. I switched the flour and cornmeal amounts. Also, I had a 1/2 pint of whipping cream that I needed to use, so I used 1c of that then added 1 1/2 c of regular milk. Usually I used buttermilk in cornbread, so I guess the whipping cream evened it out. I put veg. oil in my glass pan, covered the pan and then poured the extra into my milk mixture (after the meal had soaked in milk for 10 min). I also added a tablespoon of vanilla (just to see what would happen). This turned out great!! great color, great texture!! My family loved it. This is definately a keeper!!

text:
This is what I always thought cornbread should taste like.  It was sweet without being overpowering, and moist.  It wasn't gritty or cake-y.  It was wonderfully, sinfully delightful.   *Unfortunately it did not keep well overnight and there is quite a lot of it so I had thought it would keep better.  It dried out and lost its wonderful crust.  I wrapped in damp paper towel and microwaved it for a few seconds and it regained enough moisture to be great again, but make sure everyong eats it right out of the oven for the full experience.

text:
Great!  I made these into muffins instead,and with a little trial and error on how to bake them, the end result was very good.  I did add 1 cup of sugar, too.  Do NOT use muffin paper cups for this.  Pour 1/4 cup of batter into each well greased section and bake at 400* for 20 minutes. Makes 22-24 muffins.  Delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe exactly, and used the resulting bread as a side dish.  

This cornbread *is* very moist, and it certainly does hold-together in cleanly cut pieces.  The flavor, too, is fine...though not remarkable.  Most problematic about the cornbread that resulted from this recipe was the rubberiness that I assume is the result of lots of milk and lots of flour.  Butter, honey, and our other toppings didn't soak in; they just ran off the sides.  

I prefer a crisp crust outside and a soft, somewhat crumbly (and absorbent) inside, and so I will not be making this recipe again.

None
text:
easy and tasty.

I use the Aunt Jemima's self rising corn meal, so I just leave out the salt and baking powder.

I suggest putting a cast iron skilet or dutch oven in the oven during pre-heat.  Then take it out, spray it with non-stick vegi oil, then pour the batter in, place in oven. It gives it a nice crust.

It gets rave reviews every time I make it.

This one was GREAT!  I used it in a Texas-theme meal.  I discovered that I was out of Vegetable Oil, so used Olive oil instead and it was still yummy.  WARNING:  Because of the high milk content, it does not keep well at room temp.  It will become very stinky, slimy and GROSS if left on counter for a week by your ungrateful visiting relatives. Eaten FRESH, its VERY YUMMY!

city:

country:
None
text:
excellent cornbread recipe. I used a 9 inch round pan and it was quite tall, and moist. while soaking the corn meal, I stirred it a lot to help it absorb the milk. I also 2as trying to kill time, so I beat my eggs with a whisk until they were quite fluffy, and added the oil to that, mayonnaise-style, until I had a really nice egg/oil emulsion with lots of air trapped,and then added that to the everything else. I didn't the beat the finished mixture for a long time, just enough to get everything mixed, and it turned out beautifully. I used slightly less sugar than called for, otherwise followed the recipe, and got a nice strong corn flavour. this was probably the best cornbread I've ever made. it's really big, though! I had guests so that worked, but be warned! it makes a lot of cornbread!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my 1st time making it, and I took the advice of two people on here.
I halved the recipe so I didn't waste a bunch of ingredients if I did mess up. Did equal parts of cornmeal - flour ratio, substituted the milk for buttermilk, kept whisking every so often the cornmeal and buttermilk. I actually kept it longer than 5 mins together cause I was a mess! But that might've helped moistened the cornmeal better. Sifted flour, baking powder, salt, sugar (1/4 c white sugar) and whisked that. Then added the cornmeal mix, egg, 1/2 c melted butter, and 1/2 drained canned corn. I wasn't sure I did something wrong since my batter was not near runny, I added a bit of vegetable oil, but I think it would've been fine without. With that being said, there was in no way could I use a whisk, so I just used a wooden spatula/spoon to just mix it up. Stuck to the 5 mins mix by hand. Used a glass pyrex loaf, and set the oven at °325. It took a longer than 30 mins, not sure how long I left it in for, but went with the clean fork method and took it out to cool. For my 1st time, it was perfect. Some minor mistakes I could correct myself on, but this is the kind I love and I'm sticking to it.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is hands down the best corn bread I've ever tasted! I've been hesitant in the past few years to make corn bread because I always find it so dry and crumbly. This was incredibly moist and so delicious! I checked the comments first and made a few changed to the original recipes. 
1-I used even amounts of cornmeal and flour (1 3/4 cups each)
2-I used 1/4 melted butter and 1/4 vegetable oil.
3-I added maybe 1/4 cup of creamed corn (I was using it in another recipe anyways so thought I'd throw some in here)
4-I beat it for 5 minutes on medium high. This was an important step and you could actually see the batter getting larger in the bowl!
5-while I was beating, I put my 12" cast iron pan in the oven with about 2-3 tbsp of butter. 
I made this 3 days ago to go with some chilli. It's STILL moist and so delicious! I will definitely be making this again!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness!! I have never had such lovely cornbread.  Soft....almost like a heavy cake, no crumbling apart or dryness.  The level of sugar in the recipe was perfect in my opinion, but if you like sweet cornbread, you may want to add more sugar or honey. Mixing the ingredients with an electric beater for a full 5 min IS THE SECRET!! Seriously...set a timer and do it!  I made it following the ingredients exactly and it was wonderful!  I also made some alterations and it was wonderful too!  The 2nd batch I changed the measurements a little,  cornmeal 1 3/4c and flour 1 3/4c and add 1 can drained sweet corn.  This can be diversified with cheese or peppers, etc. What a fun recipe!  I made this with Southern Ham and brown bean soup from this site and it was too wonderful for words!

text:
12/30/18  Sweet, and very moist.  The leftovers remained moist for 4-5 days in its cassorole dish covered with foil.  The first time I made this I used a 9" pie dish.  I wouldn't recommend that, because it won't evenly bake, (batter significantly rises in the center), plus all the batter doesn't fit !  I'd baked it in the toaster oven and the top became crusty.  I like the crunchy crust on top so next time (Today !) I'll turn the broiler on near the end of bake time & see if it 'crusts.'  It's Soup Season so I especially appreciate that the carbs are much lower than other starch (roll, bread, etc.) options.  I sometimes have a piece for dessert, because it is like cake !  I bet it would pair very nicely with ice cream !!  2/4/19  I've made this several times with 2c cornmeal,  and 1.5 cups flour, as another reviewer suggested:  Now That's cornbread !  I still like the 'more like cake version :-)

Made with my own fresh ground cornmeal, this received rave reviews from the folks I made it for. The only thing I did different was to use two cups of cornmeal and two cups of flour. Followed the suggestion and gave the cornmeal a good soaking  with the milk and egg and then used my whisk to beat it well. When I make it just for my husband and me I will cut the sugar by half as I don't like sweet cornbread, but I have been making cornbread for 50 years and this recipe is definitely a keeper

None
text:
I’m not sure what all the hype is about with these reviews, this cornbread has pros and cons but wouldn’t rate it 5 stars.  
Pros:  the taste is very good, that of most of the other cornbreads I’ve tried that didn’t have any added ingredients like corn or  jalapeño  Etc.   It was fairly easy to make, I made the brewed in a glass Pyrex Esther than muffins. 
Cons:  it was way too dense.  Cornbread should be dry in the middle, airy and fluffy, and unfortunately this wasn’t.  
If anyone could suggest how to amend this recipe so the result was dry airy and fluffy Rather than a paperweight it would be great best recipe ever.

Display Name:
arctic_queen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4429929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed some advice in the comments: i used 2 cups cornmeal and let it soak for a while- like 10 minutes. or more, giving stirs a couple of times. lowered the flour to 1.5 cups, and used a hand mixer to  blend for five minutes at the end.  I melted 2 T salted butter in my dish before adding the batter. When done, the bread was about 2" tall, brown on the bottom and golden yellow on the top and so tasty!  I thought it had a bit of a bitter aftertaste, so I will have to check my baking powder, but it was not as bad as some other cornbread I have had (I am sensitive to that taste). Served this with a bowl of homemade chili con carne. This will be my recipe from now on.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I honestly can't imagine a better cornbread!  This was to die for and I've never said that about cornbread before. The adaptations I made were exactly like COOKINLOVE's: I soaked the milk and Cornbread mixture for at least 5 minutes and whisked it often. I used half a cup of sugar instead of 2/3. (Next time I will also reverse the cornbread and flour amounts because I think it would make it even better if that were possible).  I beat everything together for 5 minutes on my KitchenAid on low and while that was beating I melted 2 tablespoons of butter in a cast iron skillet in the preheated oven. I scraped the beaten mixture into the pan and then I baked it for 20 minutes. This wasn't quite long enough for me and so I put it back in for another five and it was perfect!!! We couldn't stop eating it.

text:
I used 2 cups cornmeal and 1 1/2 cups flour as others recommended, and a little less sugar. Also used butter not oil. Cooked in a 10" cast iron pan ( 1/2 stick butter melted in pan before adding batter) and it was filled to the brim. had to cook at 400 degrees  for a LONG time before it was set - probably about 40-45 minutes. I used medium grind corn meal so it still had grit even after being soaked, which we liked. Great basic recipe I will use again and keep modifying with additives like green chiles, cheese or corn.

Agreed that beating or stirring for five minutes is important.  I do think this recipe was different from the one I initially saved in my AR faves.  I couldn’t find my old school recipe box today and so sought this out on AR.  I knew something was missing, and the other reviewers state so here.  This is the best cornbread ever and the stirring is important.  I seem to recall that the stirring at the end was actually ten minutes.  I have a stand mixer so that will be no problem.  Thank you for this recipe, hubby loves this version.

text:
This was great! I made some modifications. I'm living in Athens at the moment so I decided to 'Greekify' it for fun... used olive oil, swapped the sugar with 1/3 cup Greek honey, substituted 1 cup of the milk with thinned Greek yogurt, and changed the 1 tbsp baking powder to 1 tsp baking soda to account for the increase in acidity... the result was maybe not the most traditional cornbread, but so fluffy and tasty!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
7.6.17  I made corn muffins, ended up with 16, baked the first batch for 19 minutes @ 400ºF which turned out just a little too brown around the edges, although the muffin didn’t taste overbaked.  But we eat with our eyes, so the second batch was 17 minutes, and that’s how long I’ll bake them in the future.  Only modification to the recipe was to reduce the amount of sugar (personal taste preference).  Texture is classic cornbread with a light, moist, non-crumbly texture.  We enjoyed this so much that I think this will become my go-to recipe.  Homestead Cornbread was published on this site many years ago, has had lots of reviews and is obviously still popular.

text:
Wow, what a recipe. Cornbread was my last thing to master and I'm so glad I did it this way. It looks like a lot while you're making it, but.... once it's cooled and you start digging into it you'll wish you had made more. It has all that wonderful cornbread taste with the perfect sweetness that doesn't go overboard into jiffy mix land. You'll still want to snack on this long after you finish the meal.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this cornbread. I have for years made Allrecipes Golden Sweet Cornbread. They are both good but slightly different. The Golden sweet recipe is more sweet and slightly cake like. It kind of reminds me of Boston Market cornbread. This is slightly less sweet, quite dense, yet very moist. It also rises quite tall. I would definitely make it again. I think, it could pair with more meals. I thought it had a sort of buttery flavor despite the missing butter. I used safflower oil for the oil in the recipe. I accidentally left it in the oven for about 5 minutes more and it came out perfect. Thanks!

I found this recipe years ago and it is hands down the best corn bread. I grew up in the deep Appalachian mountains where cornbread is hard as a rock and virtually tasteless. My husband always had New England style, so sweet you might think it was cake. And this bridges the gap perfectly and then some. I make it weekly and everyone loves it. country:
None
text:
This recipe is a keeper. I baked it in a buttered cast iron skillet and it turned out wonderfully moist on the inside, with a golden crust on the outside. The entire family enjoyed it. Since my husband likes "gritty" cornbread, I flip-flopped the flour and corn bread measurements, so it would have more texture. Per the author's suggestion in her own review, I beat the batter for a few extra minutes to whip more air into it. I also soaked the corn meal in the milk for 10 minutes since I used 2 cups instead of 1 1/2. Finally, I added 1 tbsp of honey, just because :)

Great cornbread, made  it exactly as the recipe says to.  It makes a big pan full, so be ready to eat a lot!  On first bite I felt like it needed either a bit more sugar or a bit more salt, depending on preference for sweet or savory cornbread, but after it sat in the pan for a day it was just right (much like how iced tea is better the second day, I suppose?).  I might try it with a touch of honey in the mixture next time to see how  goes.

text:
Was made for my birthday and enjoyed muchly. 
Changes:
- 2 cup cornmeal (not 1.5c)
- 1.5 cup flour (not 2c)
- 1 cup sugar (not 2/3c)
- less salt
- soak cornmeal & milk for 10mins
- beat for 5mins (less dense)
- covered in tin foil
- 375 degrees

text:
Printed this out years ago, and it is our go-to cornbread recipe. Over the years, I have made a few adjustments to suit our taste:reduce the sugar to 1/3 cup, increase cornmeal to 2 cups, and use 3/4 cup each of white and whole-wheat flour. If we have leftover corn in the fridge, that goes in, too! Always get compliments on this. :)
