text:
I was looking for a cornbread casserole recipe where onion, peppers and hot dogs were used.  Unfortunately they all called for corn bread mix. As I wanted to make my cornbread from scratch I found this one. I made it according to the author's directions including  beating it for 5 minutes. I added 1 1/2 c. grated cheddar cheese 3 green onions finely chopped , 1 c green pepper and 12 veggie hot dog cut up. I sprinkled 1/2c grated cheddar cheese on top. The flavour of the corn bread was exactly what I was looking for, and it was a huge hit! Next time I plan to use jalapeno peppers and grated Monterrey Jack cheese.

2c cornmeal (not 1.5c)
1.5c all purpose flour (not 2c)
1c white sugar (not 2/3c)

userID:
7624823
Display Name:
kataboon

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe twice. The first time I followed other reviewers' advice and beat the batter for longer than 5 minutes, cut the sugar in half, and cooked it in a pre-heated cast iron pan. The cornbread turned out okay but was far too dense.

The second time I made it I halved the recipe and followed the original proportions. I once again used a pre-heated cast iron pan. The only change I made to the ingredients was to add 1 tbs of vinegar to the batter just before pouring it into the hot pan. This is to activate the baking soda, creating little bubbles that end up giving the bread a slightly lighter texture.   I only beat the batter for less than a minute, following the logic that beating batter develops the gluten and results in a tougher final product. Half-way through the baking I buttered the top of the bread to give it a nice golden crust. The result was excellent! I will make it this way again for sure.
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2016-07-10T19:25:20.753

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of, if not the most moist & simple cornbread recipes I've ever tried!  Delicious hot and as leftovers.  As other reviewers suggested, I soaked the cornmeal & milk longer than instructed, used half or less sugar, and against my so-called better judgment beat the dickens out of the batter (at least 10-15 mins).  I added a can of Niblets corn and lightly remixed before baking it in a large cast iron skillet filled w/4-5 T of melted butter.  Baking time took longer than noted but it was well worth it!  We served it with turkey chili but I can't wait to try variations with diced green chilis, cheese, etc.  Thank you Canada!
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this to go with chilli & used another reviewers suggestions of 2 cups cornmeal, 1.5 cups flour, 1 cup sugar ( the rest of the ingredients as listed in the recipe). Baked for approx. 45 mins at 375. It turned out wonderfully, very moist. Put a little warmed maple syrup on the side & we all ate it with the chili AND for dessert! This is by far the best recipe I have found for cornbread...it's not too dense or dry. Caution: this won't keep for very long...eat immediately or freeze.

I will add another 1/4 of sugar next time :)

text:
Great recipe that I have made hundreds of times. Sub in white corn meal and replace some or all of the vegetable fat with equal amounts of bacon fat and you are golden. As others have stated this recipe benefits from working in some air into the batter so don't be afraid to beat it for 5 mins or so.  And addition of jalapeno and cheddar or corn niblets makes and excellent variant.

text:
I love this cornbread. I have made it numerous times, but yesterday I read some of the reviews & saw that the submitter suggested that the batter be mixed for FIVE minutes. I decided to follow that suggestion (rather than mix it as a quick bread - ie: mix dry with wet ingredients, just until combined). My cornbread came out quite dense - especially in the middle. I will go back to treating the batter more gently & enjoy the lighter crumb that I get with a quick bread method of mixing.

-Substituted the milk for water and lactose free powdered milk

text:
Amazing starter recipe. Goes good with a honey butter spread or with chili.  Super easy to customize, too. You can add  herbs to make it more savory (up the amount of salt, too) or you can add a bit more sugar to make it sweeter. You can add whole corn to add texture, or swap buttermilk for the milk.  Great texture, density, and mixes very consistently.

text:
Was pretty good, kinda sweet with the amount of sugar the recipe calls for. I'm used to using plain old Jiffy cornbread muffin mix, which is what I like, but when I moved I couldn't find Jiffy anywhere, so I made this recipe. It's not like the Jiffy stuff, but it's still good. I followed the recipe. Next time, I'll take other reviewer's suggestions and beat the batter longer and use a bit less sugar. I think that will help it taste more like the cornbread I'm used to.

EDIT: Okay, it's been a few days since I made this recipe, and I can't stand the taste of it anymore. It was way too sweet, had a funky taste, the bread itself was thick and heavy.

text:
I live in the South where cornbread typically doesn't include sugar, but I prefer this recipe over any others I've tried. I read the reviews and beat the batter for five minutes on low in a stand mixer. I also included about 2/3 cup corn because I like the look of the kernels in the bread. The cornbread was almost like a cake. It rose beautifully and came out fluffy. Everyone loved it, including my husband who isn't a huge fan of standard Southern cornbread. I have served this a few times with chili, potato soup, and a curry stew, and thought it was the perfect complement to each.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Truly fool-proof recipe! I didn't have the proper cornmeal so I used polenta.  I didn't have the proper white flour so I used unbleached flour.  Didn't have granulated white sugar either.  I had to use brown sugar and I only had 1/4 cup of that.  I did have salt and reasonably good baking powder and good eggs.  I even had to make up powdered milk!  Soaking the polenta worked great.  Thanks for the note Willowsmom.  I blended all the liquid items (milk,oil and eggs) and let it sit for 15 minutes.  I beat the batter again before adding the baking powder, salt and flour.  By then the oven was hot (which aided the baking powder). It came out great!  It absorbs butter very well.  Was great with chili.  Thanks!

This corn bread was very good. It made a large amount, good for a crowd. It was dense and held it's shape but was not dry. Other comments have mentioned the lack of corn flavor, I completely agree and will use more cornmeal and less flour in the future. However, as is, taste was great just missing a strong corn flavor. I baked for 30 minutes and mixed batter for 5 minutes as recommended by reviewers, it was perfect. Definitely will make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love, love, love, this cornbread recipe FOR CORN STICKS ONLY.  Really - our family only likes this recipe when we make it up as corn sticks *with these modifications*: swap quantities of flour/cornmeal, use whole wheat flour, use raw sugar, soak cornmeal for 5-10 minutes, bake in preheated corn stick pans w/melted butter - but not overfilling them at all - perhaps underfilling them.  For that purpose, we truly love this recipe.  Nothing else compares to the crisp crunch of this recipe when a lot of crust is involved, even when/if this recipes is not whisked for the five minutes recommended in most reviews.  Oh! the crunch when this is made with a bit of butter melted in pre-heated corn stick pans???? ---  it's really wonderful!  For other ways of baking cornbread though (muffins, in a cast iron skillet, etc.)?  We have other favorites.

country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe to the dot (even let the cornmeal sit with the milk for 5 minutes) and unfortunately, my cornbread was burnt on the edges and dry on the inside. 
This is what I suggest for the recipe: 1) The length of time the recipe suggests is too long - perhaps, 20 to 25 minutes ought to suffice. 2) Milk, egg, and butter should have been used, and mixed together first, instead of pouring in the fat (vegetable oil) near the end. 
Otherwise, I think it has potential to be a great recipe.

text:
I just made this cornbread. It was fairly moist. But I thought that it could have more corn flavour. It tasted a little watery even though there is no water in it.  I would make it again. I made a plain one in an 8 in. round pan and it took only 24 minutes in the oven. I used the rest of the batter in a glass loaf pan, I added bacon pieces to the batter and topped it with shredded cheddar cheese. That one was much more flavourful but took longer to bake.  add about 10 minutes more to baking time. It was light and fluffy inside but the outside had a hard crust since it had to bake longer. I would suggest baking it in a cake pan so it won't be as deep as the loaf pan and won't need the longer baking time.  enjoy!

text:
I don't really know the all the differences between Northern and Southern cornbread, but this recipe delivered exactly what I wanted cornbread to be:  it was moist and flavourful, with just enough sweetness and super easy to make.   
I made sure I beat the batter for 5 minutes in the mixer as WillowsMom99 recommended, I added a can of drained corn, baked it in a cast iron skillet and served it with honey butter and chili.  Everyone raved about it and had second and third helpings.  Will be my go-to cornbread recipe from now on!

Display Name:
Sue

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Based on other reviews, I made a few changes and absolutely fell in love with this cornbread!! First, I flip flopped the flour and cornmeal amounts. This helped give it a heartier flavor. Second, as it was resting for five minutes, I would give it a good whisk every minute or so. Then, after this resting period and after adding the remaining ingredients, I beat it on low speed of my electric mixer for five minutes. (Apparently this direction was part of the original recipe, but got left out somewhere along the way. But it is important because it gives the lightest texture to your finished product!) And lastly, I added a bit of honey to my batter before baking. OMGosh, it was soooo delicious!!

I'm a southerner and down here we don't add sugar to traditional cornbread, but I am here to say that this is one tradition I am willing to break. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. I have made this on several occasions including my best friend's wedding rehearsal dinner. I also swap the flour and cornmeal measurements and reduce the oven by 25 degrees. I like it a little sweeter so I add more sugar and I use brown sugar instead of white. When the bread is done I brush a little butter on top and broil it for a few minutes to give the top a nice golden brown colour. I also finely dice a jalapeño pepper with the seeds removed to give it a great smokey pepper taste and a little heat. I have never served this and ended up with left overs. I have also made a gluten free version for my girlfriend's Dad and cousin who both have gluten allergies by using rice flour and baking it a little longer. It comes out more dense and doesn't rise as well but it is still delicious!

text:
Moist and cakey and sweet, which is how we tend to like our cornbread! It was maybe just the tiniest bit flat-tasting - next time I might add more salt. (I use kosher salt, which is less salty than table salt, so that might have done it; I also used a packet of dried nonfat milk with enough water added to yield 2.5 cups, so that might be the culprit, too.) I made muffins, baked at 400 degrees for 15 minutes, and the recipe yielded 24 regular-sized muffins. This is an almost perfect recipe. Thanks!

The best cornbread I've made ever. I halved the recipe (8 servings instead of the origial 15) and followed the instructions. (First, I watched the video as I am a visual learner). I did NOT beat for 5 minutes and my bread came out great! 
It was MOIST and just the right amount of sweetness. Served it with a cajun 10 bean "soup" that I bought from the store. My husband loved it. We've made cornbread from scratch before, often using freshly ground cornmeal from a mill we visited. Ran out of that and used some regular old plain cornmeal that I've had in the fridge for about 6 months. It was perfect.

text:
This wasn't exceptional, but it wasn't terrible, either.  The only change I made from the original was that I used 1/2 c sugar instead of 2/3 c.  It was plenty sweet like that.  I beat it for a full five minutes, which resulted in large air pockets at the top and bottom of the bread and a dense center.  It was a bit dry and not all that flavorful.  This will probably not be a repeat recipe for me.

I made this corn bread last night and my whole family loved it. My husband said that I should use this recipe and nothing else, and actually wanted to eat some this morning. region:

country:
None
text:
I switched the amounts for flour and cornmeal, and sifted together flour, baking powder and salt.  I let the cornmeal soak in milk for 10 minutes before mixing everything together.  Also, I used honey instead of sugar and olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  They turned out great! If you are going to use olive oil though, make sure its good quality because you can taste it a bit.   Half the recipe made 12 muffins.

text:
This is a very good cornbread recipe.  If you like soft, moist, not-too-sweet cornbread, this is for you.  It was easy and cooked beautifully!  I have a family of 5 and could have cut the recipe in half and probably still would have had some leftover.  We are southerners who prefer sweeter, grainier cornbread.  Next time I will increase the amount of cornmeal and sugar and decrease the amount of all-purpose flour a bit.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cornbread was just the way I like it - not too sweet, not greasy, but moist on the inside and crunchy on the outside. At first I didn't think it was done because it was so light and looked bubbly, but it was done at exactly 30 minutes. I switched the flour and corn meal (as suggested by other people.) To save time, instead of mixing the batter for five minutes, I beat the eggs by themselves until it was fluffy and added it to the mix. I used Rice milk instead of regular milk and it still tasted good. For me, texture is more important than taste for corn bread, and this was the best.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is now my default cornbread recipe.  I was making it for turkey stuffing and was going to do from a mix but when I saw how simple this recipe was, I decided to give it a whirl.  It was the first time I'd ever made it from scratch and WOW!  It was SO moist and flavorful.  Just lightly sweet, not overpoweringly sweet like so many I've had.  It held it's shape when cut and didn't fall apart in my hands.  I used polenta style cornmeal and the consistency was perfect.  My husband (the world's pickiest eater) doesn't like cornbread and even he ate some and said it was good.  It was yummy with just butter, I also tried with some honey and very yummy, but my favorite so far is topped with some raspberry jam.

text:
Best 'from scratch' recipe I have found! My family of 10 has always preferred a name brand mix and I could never find a recipe that they liked. I finally did. The changes I made was using olive oil instead of veg. oil and buttermilk powder/water because I was out of milk.  I doubled the batch making one 9x13 and 4 mini loaves from it. The loaves I froze for later and we just ate them. Wonderfully moist and flavorful!

Starlet

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/100877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
PERFECT!!! Based on preference and reviews, I used a mixture of ap flour, cake flour and masa. Also, used honey for 1/4 of the sugar.  Brushed muffin tin with melted honey butter and brushed the tops as well before baking for 18 mins. Halved the recipe and got 9 good sized muffins. Hands down, the best corn bread I've ever made... A touch sweet, but not overly, good corn flavor (but I subbed part masa which adds more cornyness), no bitter aftertaste, wonderful crispy outside (honey butter helped!) soft moist inside, not at all mealy or too dry and crumbly. Might try adding some whole kernels next time, and/or a sprinkle of smoked paprika, and next time I won't halve the recipe now that I know how good it is!  UPDATE:  This freezes vey well. Made an extra loaf, froze it wrapped in foil, then a couple weeks later thawed it and threw it in a 350 oven (still wrapped in foil) for about 30m.  It was so moist and delicious!!! Next I'm gonna try cubing it and baking the cubes to make 'croutons' to use in stuffing =)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making cornbread from scratch. I wasn't sure how this would turn out b/c the directions didnt specify whether to use self rising corn meal or regular. Also the pan size wasn't mentioned on the original recipe that I printed(from a while ago). I now see that a pan size has been added.  I bought self rising and cooked it in a 9" round pan. I didn't add all the sugar it called for, I used just barely over 1/2 cup. I had to cook it for almost 50 minutes for the middle to cook completely. Once it was FINALLY done, it tasted great. The top was a little crunchy, next time I'll cook it at 375 for 60 minutes. That should make it about perfect. I will def. be making this again though. Bye bye Jiffy!!

text:
If you like typical "American" food meaning VERY SWEET or VERY GREASY then this bread is not for you.  This is a very subtle bread and is delicious.  I too followed others suggestions and switched the Corn meal amt and the flour amt.  I also used a Medium coarse corn meal.  When it was done baking I brushed on a little melted butter and honey.   This bread is awesome and a keeper.  If you are looking for a typical American corn muffin (like in bakeries around the US) this is not for you.  This is what real food should taste like!

Used this cornbread recipe last week and everyone really enjoyed the cornbread.  I did switch the cornmeal and flour as suggested by other reviewers and it worked great.  Made again yesterday for a crowd of 50 to go with a pot of my homemade vegetable beef soup.  Was a huge hit.  Nice and moist, the best cornbread I have made from scratch, ever.  Will use this as my basic cornbread mix from now on.  Had some left overs that I put in the freezer to use when I make cornbread dressing at Christmas.  I used Splenda in place of sugar and worked great.  I did reduce the amount of sweeter used because I did not want the cornbread sweet this time since the soup had a touch of Splenda to counter the acid of the tomatoes.  Thanks for the tasty cornbread recipe.

This recipe was pretty good, although I did make a few changes.  First of all, I cut the recipe in half.  I substituted honey for the sugar and melted butter for the veggie oil. text:
This was good, but not "the best I've ever had."  It's the same as the packaged stuff you'd find in the baking aisle... so if it's cheaper for you to make it from scratch and you have all the ingredients on hand, then it's worth it.  It tasted very average to me and seems like a good starting point for customizing... adding ingredients to make your personal touch. It wasn't good warm out of the oven and we had to wait until it was room temperature before anyone liked it.  And then, like I said, it was just average. I'm not fond of making things from scratch to come up with "average" so I'll probably spend the $2 and buy the package next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
A great recipe that yields a big pan of delicious cornbread! I did end up making a few modifications though. I soaked the cornmeal in only 2 cups of milk for 10 minutes.In addition, since I like my cornbread chunky, I added a whole can of drained whole kernal corn to the batter. However, I reserved half a cup of the corn "juice" from the can and added it to the batter, rather then the additional half a cup of milk, giving it an even richer corn flavor. Overall, the cornbread was very moist, dense,not too sweet, and had a great flavor.

text:
I baked this cornbread before reading the most recent reviews which expressed concern about the recipe, however, it turned out just fine for us.  I served it with flank steak seasoned with a spicy mexican dry rub and black beans with jalapenos and the sweetness of the cornbread was a very nice balance with the spicy steak and beans.  I will say it tasted less "corny" than other cornbreads I have made.  Next time I might swap the flour measurement with the cornmeal measurement.  The texture was nice...it was a high riser.

text:
I have made this too many times to count and it always turns out great! Normally, I reduce serving size to 6 and use 1 egg instead of less than one egg. I mix ground beef with salsa, cumin and chili powder and put in pan, spread cheddar cheese and sliced black olive then pour cornbread batter over (2.8 liter casserole dish). Cook for about 30 minutes at 395 degrees (or longer if you like drier cornbread). Always turns out great! I have made lots of cornbread looking for the best one and I think this is it. Soaking in milk for 10 minutes is the key for me.

text:
Perfect! Just Perfect! I have been searching for a cornbread recipe, and after 5 or 6 different recipes (or imposters) I found this one! The only change I made was that I switched around the amounts of Flour and Cornmeal. I didn't even wait the 5 minutes so the cornmeal could soak. I just threw it all together and it was UNREAL. It was thick and rich, with the perfect amount of sweetness. It isn't one of those fluffy sort of conbreads. It is dense and full of flavor. The Yellow Cornmeal just gives it the most gorgeous color too. Perfect crust on the outside, too. I can't say enough about it. It's amazing. My new cornbread recipe.

text:
I found this to be a great recipe. My boyfriend is lactose intolerant and allergic to wheat so I substituted 3/4 cup rice flour for every cup of wheat flour. As well, I substituted the milk for vanilla flavoured rice milk. I soaked the cornmeal for a good 15 minutes. Instead of baking it in a large baking dish, I made muffins. I don't think I will do this again as the cornbread really stuck to the paper muffin cups. Regardless, however, the cornbread turned out nice and moist and the taste is wonderful with just the perfect amount of sweetness. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Very EASY to make. I'm an American living in Australia and every year we host a 4th of July BBQ.  This year I made this to go with some veggie chili. Everyone raved about this bread - many have never had cornbread before.  The guests were eating even if they didn't have the chili.  I made this the night before and just popped back in the oven to re-heat for about 10 mins before serving.  Best if served warm. The little that we had left over we ate with breakfast the next morning- I would recommend toasting however-  toasted on a hot plate or griddle.  I will be making this again.

text:
I tinkered with this recipe so much, I'm not sure what the original product is supposed to taste like. I switched the ratios of cornmeal and flour. I put in half whole wheat for the flour. I used flaxseed meal instead of veg. oil. i threw in corn, onions, and pepperjack cheese. I used yogurt instead of milk. I baked it in a cast iron skillet. I only used half the recipe. I will eat this for the rest of the week, and be happy.

text:
This cornbread is exactly what the doctor ordered for my daughter and I! My mother, more of a Kentucky traditionalist, disagrees, prefering, instead, the dry non-sweet bread she knew in her youth. But, we just come back for more of this wonderful treat! We eat it various ways, both just with butter or margerine, all the way to slicing it and serving it like a cornbread pancake. It is easy, and easily worth the little trouble it is. We have also switched the amount of flour down, and the cornmeal up, as other commentors recommend. It's just a variation on the prize. Try this one!

Maybe I will try it again in a 9x13 pan like the recipe calls for and then I will hopefully have better luck.

So be careful and only follow the online recipe.  I will definately try again.

text:
My husband absolutely hates cornbread and I love it so I've never attempted to make it at home. I made chili and this cornbread and I saw from the corner of my eye that he snuck a little corner of my piece....I didn't say anything. Then he got up from the table and came back with a piece of it with a big grin on his face and quietly sat down like nothing happened. When he looked up he saw me staring at him and we both cracked up laughing because he swore he would never go near cornbread.....until now. I call this the miracle cornbread and it's a keeper.
